@sarbjeetjohal @javajag @rwang0 @Apple Think of it like a grocery store. Why do we go there versus buying from every manufacturer and producer? Trust and convenience. Are there markups in the distribution channel? Yep. Same goes for the App Store.

@sarbjeetjohal @javajag @rwang0 @Apple One-time purchases or subscriptions are both a transaction where you are a) paying for a product and b) paying for updates to that product. The App Store creates a marketplace for products (apps) as well as conduit for the transactions.

What can CIOs learn from the Southwest Airlines debacle?

#CIO #Risk #Strategy #Southwest https://t.co/D5tDoQM8We

@sarbjeetjohal @javajag @rwang0 @Apple Those models are not comparable.

The business models are completely different. In addition, the sheer magnitudes of volume difference drive much of this too.

@sarbjeetjohal @javajag @rwang0 @Apple @Google I find this an interesting argument.

What is the difference between running a business that benefits all stakeholders (customers, partners, employees, shareholders) and greed? Where exactly does that line lie?

Is @SouthwestAir's crew scheduling system the culprit? Or is it the business model that Southwest has chosen to take? Or a combination of both? Or neither?

I'm breaking this down with insights to come.

#CIO #data #SouthwestAirlines #Southwest #travel

@sarbjeetjohal @javajag @rwang0 @Apple This is great for enterprises that may want to stand up their own App Store.

The downside is a loss of control (both good and bad) for Apple and users.

@sarbjeetjohal @javajag @rwang0 What I don‚Äôt know is: There are FAA policies around managing crew schedules that will likely challenge a quick solution.

This is where governance and operations collide.

@javajag @rwang0 @sarbjeetjohal Not surprising. Having worked with major airlines the answer is not a simple one. Just ‚Äòupgrading‚Äô is not nearly as easy as it sounds. The trade off is when things go sideways, they really go sideways.

@CTOAdvisor There is a lot of opportunity, but not a lot of solutions around hybrid cloud management along the edge-to-cloud continuum. 

Companies like @HPE and @NetApp are trying to head in that direction. But there is a LOT of work to be done.

You have to separate who they are from who they aspire to be.

Who they are: A storage company.
Who they aspire to be: A cloud data management company.

There's a pretty sizable gap between the two. Brand perception also plays a significant role.

The problem isn't a lack of concern. It is a balance between perspectives. And the balance has been off kilter for a long time.

We really, REALLY need to rethink usability when it comes to 2FA, MFA and password managers.

Often there is too much focus on the security risks and not enough on the usability.
